greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = number of Jacobsthal numbers (A001045) needed to sum to n using the greedy algorithm.
comment: Sum of digits in "Jacobsthal greedy base", A265747.
It would be nice to know for sure whether this sequence gives also the least number of Jacobsthal numbers that add to n, i.e., that there cannot be even better nongreedy solutions.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..10923
formula: a(0) = 0; for n >= 1, a(n) = 1 + a(n - A001045(A130249(n))). [This formula uses a simple greedy algorithm.]
example: a(0) = 0, because no numbers are needed to form an empty sum, which is zero.
For n=1 we need just A001045(2) = 1, thus a(1) = 1.

For n=6 we form the greedy sum as A001045(4) + A001045(2) = 5 + 1, thus a(6) = 2. Alternatively, we could form the sum as A001045(3) + A001045(3) = 3 + 3, but the number of summands in that case is no less.
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Dec 17 2015
